dt: {bc}the part between the shoulder and the wrist
{bc}something like or corresponding to an arm: such as
{bc}a branch or lateral shoot of a plant
{bc}a slender part of a structure, machine, or an instrument projecting from a main part, axis, or fulcrum
{bc}the part of an anchor from the crown to the fluke {dx}see {dxt|anchor|anchor|illustration}{/dx}
{bc}any of the usually two parts of a chromosome lateral to the centromere
{bc}an inlet of water (as from the sea)
{bc}a narrow extension of a larger area, mass, or group
{bc}a support (as on a chair) for the elbow and forearm
{bc}the ability to throw or pitch a ball well
{bc}a functional division of a group, organization, institution, or activity

dt.t: the logistical {wi}arm{/wi} of the air force

dt: {bc}a group of subjects provided a particular treatment in a {d_link|clinical trial|clinical trial}

dt.t: Since this trial did not include a radiation-only treatment {wi}arm{/wi}, it has been questioned whether radiation therapy alone might be as effective as sequential chemotherapy and radiation therapy in preserving the larynx.

et: Middle English, going back to Old English {it}earm, arm,{/it} going back to Germanic{it} *arma-,{/it} masculine, (whence also Old Frisian {it}erm{/it} "arm," Old Saxon {it}arm,{/it} Old High German {it}aram, arm,{/it} Old Norse {it}armr,{/it} Gothic {it}arms{/it}), going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}orH-mo-,{/it} whence also Old Church Slavic {it}ramo{/it} {ldquo}shoulder,{rdquo} Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian {it}rȁme,{/it} stem {it}rȁmen-,{/it} Czech {it}ráměk{/it}; a parallel zero-grade {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}r̥H-mó-{/it} gives Old Prussian {it}irmo{/it} {ldquo}arm,{rdquo} Lithuanian (eastern dialects) {it}ìrmėdė{/it} {ldquo}pain from gout, chill, fever{rdquo} ({it}irm-{/it} {ldquo}arm{rdquo} + {it}-ėdė{/it} {ldquo}eating{rdquo}), Sanskrit {it}īrmá-{/it} {ldquo}arm,{rdquo} Avestan {it}arəma-{/it}; Latin {it}armus{/it} {ldquo}forequarter (of an animal), shoulder{rdquo} probably goes back to {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}erH-mo-{/it}

Usually claimed to be a derivative of the verb {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}er-{/it} {ldquo}fit, join{rdquo} (see {et_link|arm:3|arm:3})—very plausible semantically—though the Sanskrit and Baltic forms require a second laryngeal ({it}*h{inf}2{/inf}erH-{/it}) in the base (cf. Rix et al., {it}Lexikon der indogermanischen Verben,{/it} 2. Auflage, Wiesbaden, 2001, where the verbal base is posited without a second laryngeal). Could the suffix be {it}*-H-mo-{/it}? The Slavic noun fluctuates in inflection between {it}-mo-{/it} and {it}-men-{/it} (see André Vaillant, {it}Grammaire comparée des langues slaves,{/it} II:1 [Lyon, 1958], pp. 214-15). According to P. Schrijver, {it}The Reflexes of the Proto-Indo-European Laryngeals in Latin{/it} (Amsterdam, 1991), p. 194, Latin {it}armus{/it} cannot be traced to {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}r̥H-mo-,{/it} which would have yielded {it}*ramus.{/it} Regarding Armenian {it}armukn{/it} {ldquo}elbow,{rdquo} see H. K. Martirosyan, {it}Etymological Dictionary of the Armenian Inherited Lexicon,{/it} Leiden, 2010, s.v.
shortdef: a human upper limb; especially : the part between the shoulder and the wrist
something like or corresponding to an arm: such as

dt: {bc}a means (such as a weapon) of offense or defense
{bc}an organized branch of national defense (such as the navy)
{bc}the hereditary heraldic devices of a family
{bc}aroused and ready to undertake a fight or conflict

et: Middle English {it}armes{/it} (plural), "weapons, the military profession, heraldic devices," borrowed from Anglo-French, plural of {it}arme{/it} "weapon," going back to Latin {it}arma{/it} (neuter plural) "implements of war, weapons, equipment," derivative, with a suffix {it}*-mo-,{/it} from a presumed verbal base {it}*ar-,{/it} going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}er-{/it} {ldquo}fit, join,{rdquo} whence Greek reduplicated aorist {it}ḗraron{/it} "(I) fit together, equipped, fit closely" (from which present tense {it}ararískō, ararískein{/it}), {it}ármenos{/it} (middle participle) {ldquo}fitting, suited to,{rdquo} and (with suffixed {it}*-smo-{/it} giving initial aspiration?) {it}harmós{/it} {ldquo}joint,{rdquo} {it}hárma, harmat-{/it} {ldquo}chariot, team of horses{rdquo}; Armenian {it}arari{/it} "(I) made," {it}aṙnem{/it} {ldquo}I make{rdquo}
shortdef: a means (such as a weapon) of offense or defense; especially : firearm
a combat branch (as of an army)
an organized branch of national defense (such as the navy)
